posts.title: The Future of Digital Design Systems
posts.excerpt: Discover how atomic design principles are reshaping the way teams build products. Learn to create consistent, scalable interfaces that users love.
posts.content:
Why Atomic Design Matters

When we break down interfaces into their smallest components, we gain flexibility. Atomic design is not a linear process, but a mental model to help us think of our user interfaces as a cohesive whole and a collection of parts at the same time.

The Atoms

Atoms are the basic building blocks of matter. Applied to web interfaces, atoms are our HTML tags, such as a form label, an input or a button.

Design systems are about people, not just pixels.

By focusing on the atomic level, we ensure consistency across the entire application.

posts.title: Mastering Tailwind CSS Grid
posts.excerpt: Stop fighting with layout. We break down the most confusing parts of CSS Grid and how to use them effectively in your next project.
posts.content:
Grid vs Flexbox

The most common question I get is: When should I use Grid and when should I use Flexbox?

The general rule of thumb is: CSS Grid is for layout (2D), and Flexbox is for alignment (1D).

Setting up the Grid

<div class="grid grid-cols-3 gap-4">
  <div>1</div>
  <div>2</div>
  <div>3</div>
</div>

This simple class creates a three-column layout that would have taken 20 lines of CSS just a few years ago.

posts.title: Building Accessible Forms
posts.excerpt: Accessibility is not optional. Here is a checklist of Aria labels, focus states, and semantic HTML tags you should never forget.
posts.content:
The Importance of Semantic HTML

Using the correct HTML tag is 80% of the work. Screen readers rely on tags like <button>, <nav>, and <main> to understand the structure of your page.

Focus States

Never remove the default outline on focus unless you replace it with something better. Users navigating via keyboard rely on this visual cue to know where they are on the page.

posts.title: Refactoring Legacy Codebases
posts.excerpt: Strategies for modernizing old applications without rewriting everything from scratch. Learn the strangler fig pattern.
posts.content:
Don't Rewrite Everything

The temptation to 'burn it down' and start over is strong, but often leads to failure. Instead, try incremental refactoring.

The Strangler Fig Pattern

This pattern involves creating a new system around the edges of the old system, slowly intercepting calls and replacing functionality piece by piece until the old system can be safely removed.
